chunk_text: Acute asthma exacerbations require prompt recognition and treatment. The severity should be assessed using clinical parameters including respiratory rate difficulty speaking and oxygen saturation. Mild exacerbations may be managed with bronchodilators alone while severe cases require systemic corticosteroids and close monitoring.
chunk_summary: Clinical approach to acute asthma management in pediatric patients

chunk_text: Heart murmurs in children require careful evaluation to distinguish innocent from pathologic murmurs. Innocent murmurs are typically soft systolic and change with position or activity. Pathologic murmurs may be associated with symptoms growth failure or abnormal cardiac examination findings.
chunk_summary: Evaluation and differentiation of heart murmurs in pediatric patients

chunk_text: Motor development follows a predictable sequence in healthy children. By 6 months most infants can sit with support and transfer objects between hands. By 12 months walking with assistance and pincer grasp are typically achieved. Delays in motor milestones warrant further evaluation for underlying neurologic or developmental disorders.
chunk_summary: Overview of normal motor development milestones in infancy and early childhood

chunk_text: Febrile seizures occur in 2-5% of children between 6 months and 5 years of age. Simple febrile seizures are generalized last less than 15 minutes and do not recur within 24 hours. Complex febrile seizures have focal features prolonged duration or recurrence. Most children with simple febrile seizures have excellent outcomes with low recurrence risk.
chunk_summary: Clinical features and management of febrile seizures in children

chunk_text: Antibiotic selection in pediatric patients requires consideration of the likely pathogen patient age and weight drug penetration to the infection site and local resistance patterns. Empiric therapy should be narrowed once culture results are available. Duration of therapy varies by infection type and clinical response.
chunk_summary: Principles of antibiotic selection and duration in pediatric infectious diseases

chunk_text: Atopic dermatitis is a chronic inflammatory skin condition affecting up to 20% of children. Management includes appropriate moisturization topical anti-inflammatory agents and trigger avoidance. Severe cases may require systemic therapy or specialist referral. Patient education about the chronic nature is essential.
chunk_summary: Comprehensive management approach for pediatric atopic dermatitis

chunk_text: Acute gastroenteritis is a leading cause of morbidity in children worldwide. Most cases are viral in origin and self-limited. The primary concern is prevention of dehydration through appropriate fluid and electrolyte replacement. Oral rehydration therapy is preferred when tolerated.
chunk_summary: Management of acute gastroenteritis focusing on hydration and symptom control

chunk_text: ADHD diagnosis requires evidence of inattention hyperactivity-impulsivity symptoms present before age 12 causing impairment in multiple settings. Symptoms must persist for at least 6 months and be inappropriate for developmental level. Standardized rating scales and comprehensive history are essential diagnostic tools.
chunk_summary: Diagnostic approach and criteria for ADHD in children and adolescents
